text: Taikurissa 1/2017. Very nice, full-bodied warming dark wheat beer. Malty and enjoyable.

Bottle. Pours a reddish brown with a large, latte-colored head. Aroma is chocolate, roast, dark fruit. Taste is slightly roasted, caramel, spice, slight chocolate, dark fruit. Smooth. Rather stout-like. Not much in the way of a dunkelweizen here. Perhaps a dunkelweizenbockish beer?

Medium aroma with sweet, dark fruits, chocolate and some alcohol bite. Black color with small, light beige head. Medium, balanced taste with dark fruits and chocolate, lightly roasted malts, some wheat and a hint of nuts. Medium taste spectrum and medium aftertaste with sweetish malts. Medium body with log/medium carbonation. Overall, wheat doesnt feel so much, but still strong and balanced product.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown black color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy caramel aroma. Fruity wheat malty spicy caramel flavor. Has a fruity wheat malty spicy caramel finish.
Once again Anchor Brewing doesnt disappoint. Wheat beers arent my favorite, but this is one enjoyable beer.

Bottle. Black in color with a tan head. Sweet dark fruits, mild roasted notes in aroma. Some cocoa too. The wheat appears later on, very mild though. Sweet malty tast, some chocolate as well. Bit dry. Light spicy finish. In a blindtasting I would have guessed this to be somekind of Belgian dubbel with a small wheaty twist. Dried dark sweet fruity aftertaste.

Pours black with a medium foamy tan head. Aromas of chocolate, roasted malt, roasted nuts, spices, lactose. Taste is chocolatey and roasted with moderate bitterness and a slight fruitiness. A really good winter ale.

Bottle from Appellation Wines. Pours dark brown which was a bit shock as I expected it to be pale. Brown head. Nose is sweet dark malts, dark fruits, some liquorice, light roast, sweet wheaty notes. Tastes very malty, quite smooth, gentle roast and light bitter, quite rich. Solid, has something winterish in it, malty, sweetish. Better than expected.
Olmost black with brown head - Malt aroma - Malt body with some dark fruity flavours as well - The malt flavours goes into the finish - This was good
Pours brown to red with a beige head, aroma of chocolate, caramel, honey, fruits, flavor of chocolate, caramel, honey, fruits, nuts, medium bodied

Poured black color with a thin brown head. 
Roasted nuts, malts, burnt notes. Medium to full bodied. Sweet, berries, ashy, roasted malts. Decent. Dry finish.

Roasty wheats, weak dry chocolate, dry malty. Med bldied, easy, light boozy. Some tar even. Bit spicy, dark wheaty ale.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone
One of my favorite beer! Pours gold colour beer with a medium head. Well-balanced!

Slightly murky brown, with a tall dark beige head. Aromas of dark fruit and wheat (from pale to lightly roasted). Lightly sweet, matching the aromas. A bit earthy. A dunkelweisse with not much yeast character
Pours a dark brown body with a thin beige head. Aroma of dried fruit. Very nice taste with tones of bread and other malty notes.

Like a busy little dog: its sweet + its nose has a lot going on. Roasted malt nose: hot chocolate/caramel; prunes/dates; weak cinnamon/star anise; possibly a fruity bag of coffee/mocha? Chewy, milky choc milkshake-y/caramel-y coca-cola middle, before bitterness round its off relatively quickly. Very slight cinnamon/star anise flavour on the aftertaste? Sweetness balanced well. Much more Dubbel (or at least milk stout) than a Dunkel Weizen (which would be relatively thin compared to this). Surprising, in a good way.

Bottle from Wholefoods Kensington, London. Pours deep, rich and dark brown with a large off white foam head. Nose is sweet, lacticky, milky, black sugar, roasted malt, little liqurice, prune, plum, mainly sweetness. Taste is sweet, roasted malt, prune, plum, dried fruit, milky and lactic. Really like this. Blaance of sweetness is really nice. Hope this is a regular.
Bottle. Pours a black colour with a thin beige head, aroma is malty with wheat, the taste is medium bitterness and smooth in the mouth with a dry bitter finish.
Interesting and unexpected. Pours very dark. Sweet malty nose with bananas and esters. Noticeable alcohol. Sweet finish. A blend of styles. Highly drinkable and reasonably compelling. Bottle.

On tap at Brunzies (12/18/15). Sweet malty nose with a hint of gingerbread and biscuit. A little tang. Dark brown with thin head. Medium body with medium carbonation. Sweet body, malty with gingerbread. Light nutty finish and understated hop bitterness. Sweet after.

bottle @ home. Almost opaque black with a creamy, long lasting tan head and a beautiful thin film of lace. Sweet, fruity and spicy nose up front with a solid wheat aroma, dark bread, cinnamon, some clove, nicely integrated ripe bananas, fruity coffee. Medium bodied with a smooth texture. Sweet with a dry finish. Flavor is more roasted than whats evident in the aroma. Notes of wheat, dark bread, syrup, cloves, banana. coffee, some fudge. Aftertaste, which comes without much duration is dry and has dark chocolate, cinnamon, anise, charcuteries, orange zest and coffee. Bitter, slightly roast-sour finish
0,355l bottle from Systembolaget Övertorneå. Pours very dark brown with a medium mocha head. Aroma is sweet roasted malts. Flavor is sweet roasted malts and banana. Great.

Deep cola brown color. Enormous french-press mocha coffee head. Leaves thick gobs of lace on the top rim of the glass.

The aroma is cola too: sweet, dark corn syrup. Cinnamon and winter spices. Combination of dark malts and spice. This aroma is on some legit German dark wheat s__t right here. Whatever roast is there is immediately softened by the sugars. Im wowed by the Coke aroma.

The sugary malts are soft and full of more cinnamon and Christmas spices. Caramel and a sort of tawny, rather nutty finish.

Feels chalky at first and then with a slick finish. This is one of the most authentic non-German German beers Ive had in a long time. This would fit right in any Oktoberfest. Love this beer and wish I had more.
UPDATED: APR 28, 2017 From TJs. Interesting stuff, a dunkelweizen and a baltic porter had a baby and it turned out alright and more more easy drinking than it sounds. Serving: Bottle

Bottle. Deep brown color with a thick foamy beige head. Aroma of bread and roasted malt. Dry taste with some bitterness. Medium thick body. This doesnt smell or taste like a dunkelweizen.-- rated with beerbasher/winphone

As dark as a stout with a large tan head and very good lacing. Ripe, dark fruit aroma with hints of licorice and wheat bread. Smooth, spicy wheat flavors focused on stone fruit and sweet malts. Hops leave only a light footprint. ABV is well hidden. Medium-to-full bodied, softly carbonated mouthfeel leading to a long lasting finish.

Bottle 12fl.oz. [ As Anchor Winter Wheat ].Unclear dark black brown color with a small large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, light brown head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, wheat, moderate roasted and chocolate, moderate to light heavy yeasty, banana. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and light to moderate bitter with a long duration, roasted - chocolate, wheat, yeast - wiezen yeast. Body is medium, texture is oily - creamy, carbonation is soft. [20160109]

OK, when I ordered this, I got a dark brew and I asked, judging form the name, if I got the right tap or not. It is so surprisingly big and black. Has a roasty aroma about it. Quite strong on the initial uptake. Comes across like a baltic porter. I cant remember a dunkel that I had ever being over 6%, so Im not sure if this actually is in the right style here. Roasty flavors and it seems a little burned. Yes, this is certainly not what I was expecting when I saw whet. Big black porter finish as well. Some leather in the end. A little more than I was expecting for a wheat or a dunkel. The bad manners this presents will give the uninitiated a bad feel for dunkels.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Very pleasantly surprised by this. Wasnt expecting so much malty chocolate and coffee.Great thick boozy (but not in the taste) dunkel. Like a wheaty stout.

Anchor Winter Wheat is a hearty brew for the Winter season. Pours a medium dark brown with a thick tan head that holds up well. Aroma of wheat and malt. Taste is nice wheaty flavor with a good malt backbone and notes of stone fruit. Winter Wheat will keep you warm wherever you are.

12 oz. bottle from The Party Source. Pours an opaque brown with a big tan head that forms a lasting cap and leaves heavy lace in the glass. Looks great, really. Notes of toast, chocolate, cardboard, earth, brown sugar, soy, and dark fruits. Medium-bodied, with medium carbonation and an earthy, malty, roasty, toasty mouthfeel. Oxidized, but this is last winters Winter Wheat. My fault. Ill rate a fresh one if I get a chance.

Bottle from systembolaget.
Darn brown black, brown head 
Aroma of caramel cherries, some burned notes.
Sweet full flavor.

Bottle from systembolaget. 
Pours black with a tan head. 
Aroma of roasted malts and chocolate. 
Sweet, dark chocolate, coffee and a little wheat.

How: Bottle.
Where: Systembolaget.
Appearance: Almost black colour with a beige head.
Aroma: Roasted malt, fruit, alcohol, chocolate.
Body: Medium body and carbonation.
Flavour: <Chocolate, some spices, roasted malt, alcohol.
Aroma is sweet brown sugars, slight chocolates, dark bread and raisins. Taste is wheaty malty, nuts, mild coffee notes, spices and a slight warming finish.

Pours clear reddish black, medium brown head, creamy with nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is roasty, wheat, pumpernickel breads. Flavor is medium sweet and very light bitter, roasted wheats, faint smoky notes. Medium body, slight astringency
Mmm, alltså det här var ju inte dumt. Smaken bar toner av karamell, råsocker och jord. Balansen satt inte helt på plats men kroppen var stabil.

12oz bottle from the state store 
Pours dark brown with a small beige head, light lacing. Aroma of toasted malts, bready, nutty and chocolate. Flavors of dark malts, chocolate, ashy with a bitter, dry finish 
Decent but not a fan of this one.

Bottle @ Linko, Helsinki. Pours black with a little brownish head - very black for a dunkelweizen. The aroma is light to medium roasty with raisin and other dark fruity elements and pushing through, also a touch of spiciness - intriguing. Taste is medium sweet and rich in flavours; roastiness is kept in check and fills only a supporting role. Wheat, yeasty spiciness and dark fruitiness are most prominent. Nicely balanced despite a wide set of different, even contrasting flavours. The palate is medium-bodied and smooth, low on carbonation. Simply excellent - has all the characteristics a proper winter wheat beer needs to have.

Single bottle from Trader Joes. Late at night, drudgering at the computer, I just wanted "a" beer. Find this much distinctive than I could expect. Pours a dark brown body with a stiff brown head that remains standing in my wheat ale glass. Smell carries ideas about banana bread and walnut, before making with a warm malt smell. Not a lot of alcohol in the nose. Hold the first sip on my tongue (because I have a new filling in one tooth that complains whenever something cold comes near it). Theres a bit of cardamon from wheat malt and a weizen yeast ferment. Stiff malts and a tickle of noble hops prevail. Alcohol does not detract from taste, instead adding some mellow smoothness as it builds up in my lobes. Cant help it, I just find this to be an excellent beer at the right time.

Pretty good. The fact that it was a dunker surprised me in a good way. Pours really dark with little head. Smells of malt and chocolate. Tastes of bread, chocolate, pumpernickel and perhaps a bit of licorice. Enough going on to make you think. It's hearty and at 7% it'll warm you up on a winter night.

Dark brown to black pour with a one finger creamy tan head. Aroma is sweet wheat, molasses, caramel, light dusty chocolate, dark fruit and some clove spice. Flavor is chocolate, caramel, toasted sweet wheat bread, dark fruit, clove and cinnamon spice, light earthy hops, licorice, a little soy sauce and earthy woodiness. Medium body, slightly syrupy entry, dry finish and medium, blanketing and somewhat sharp carbonation. Good stuff overall, solid Dunkelweizen.

Bottle, bought @Systembolaget, Hyltebruk. Pours deep, almost opaque black with a large, staying creamy beige head. Aroma has sweet malts, roasted, wheat. A bit mild in aroma. Low carbonation, fine dry and light creamy mouthfeel. Flavour has good sweet wheat, roasted malts, nuts, chocolate. Lovely warming and quite malty dry finish.
Dark brown appearance. Roasted bready malt with a sprucey after taste and a bit of chocolate.

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with faint red highlights and a huge foamy brown head that lingered and left excellent lacing. The aroma was malty, wheaty and bready with molasses, dark fruit and an herbal presence. The flavor was bitter and very malty with bread dough, molasses, wheat, dark fruit and an herbal note. Long finish. Moderately full body. Interesting.

Bottle from The Beerhive. Black body with a thin tan head. Good lacing. Aroma of charred wood, burnt toast, Marmite, dark chocolate, parma violets and flower petals. Flavour of roasted malt, fruit pudding, spices and blueberries. Medium body with a smooth, creamy texture. Soft fizz. An unusual beer thats rich and flavoursome. I really enjoyed this.
Pours a medium brownish color with tan colored head. Wheat, spice, some roasted malts, and a light grass on the nose; follows onto the palate. Medium bodied. Finishes with spice and wheat. Nice.
Bottle from Bottlecraft, Hanley. Pours mud brown with a light haze. Nice sweet Dunkelweizen, true to style. Some spice. Good.

@ Havregatan 160116. Bottle (355 ml) from Systembolaget. Roasted malty, fruity and sweet with spicy notes and chocolate, medium body with an oily texture. The finish is medium bitter, roasted, sweet and fruity.
355 ml bottle. Black body with a low head. Sort of sweet malty porter like aroma, but flavor is more roasted with liquorice, coffee, herbal notes and chocolate.
Svart med fingerhøyt lys brunt skum. Luktet kaffe, korn og mørke frukter. Middels fylde. Starter ganske lett, søtlig. Saltsmaken kommer utover. Lakris, mørk sjokolade og jord, animalsk smak.

Bottle, 7%. Very dark brown with small beige head. Aroma is malt, yeast, dark fruit and plume. Flavour is malt, caramel, yeast, dark fruit, plume, medium sweet, hop, little chocolate and a little bitter.
Bottle @ my place. Nice head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are rich chocolate, fruits, caramel and hops. Nice bitter finish.

Bottle @ Saxo tasting. Clear very dark brown with a light brown head. Aroma is sweet, malty, caramel, chocolate and yeasty. Flavor is quite sweet and light bitter. Sweet and light bitter finish. 090116
Not too much aroma. Great flavour- well rounded, toffee, licorice, darkness, prunes, cloves. Finish is quite bitter. Holds up well against Aventinus which obviously inspired it.

Svart med ett riktigt brunt skum. Doft: Godis, mörk mjuk kryddigkaka, bränt socker, rosa tuggummi, smörkola, lite söt spya, malt. Smak: Som doft i stort fast mer rosa tuggummi + alkohol och artificiella toner.

Appearance was red tinged opaque with creamy beige diminishing 1 finger head, no lacing. Aromas are soft chocolate, nuts, clean cut wheat with hints of deep sugars. Taste are milk coffee latte upfront then light roasted malts come to play. The soft deep fruits of cherry, date then smooth soft English, American yeast finish. Palate was soft creamy CO2 with medium-light body, then a beautiful lasting slightly slick Porter-like toasty finish. Overall an interesting brew with complex and fantastic smooth finish.
Bottle (355 ml) from Systembolaget. Dark brown, medium beige head. Nutty, slightly chocolatey aroma, some herbal hops. Medium to full bodied, medium carbonation.

Bottle. Opaque dark brown beer with a large beige head. Aroma is spicy with notes of caramel,bread, molasses, coffee and herbs. Flavor is malty with notes of caramel, bread, molasses, coffee and chocolate. Well balanced.

12 oz bottle. Pours black with tall, long lasting, fluffy, brown head and nice lacing. Aroma is of toasted malt, piney hops and dark fruit. Body is full and smooth. Taste is of toasted malt, chocolate, vanilla, brown sugar, dark fruit and herbal hops. Finish is long and semi-dry. Delicious brew

(bottle) Glad to find some of this around this season, as I came up empty-handed in my quest for it last season. Pours pretty much jet-black with a medium dark tan head that quickly dissipates to a thin tan ring of foam. I wouldnt judge this as a wheat beer based on its appearance. Aroma holds doughnuts/fritters (apple cinnamon), dates, chocolate, and roasted malt. None of the standard banana notes here, but their absence is easily forgotten due to the presence of the other scents which have taken their stead. Taste is dark fruit forward, with flavors of plum and date showing up initially that transitions to cola, then chocolate, and finally the chalky/tart wheat flies in on the finish to remind one that theyre drinking a wheat beer. There could be a glimmer of peppermint here. Mouthfeel is creamy and carbonation is to style. Im glad I was able to track some of this down, as its a very solid dunkel/weizenbock.

flaska från SB. Mörk mahogny, lågt krämigt skum. En väldigt välbalanserad vetebock med fina rostade smaker, lätt syrlighet, mycket torkad mörk frukt. Smakerna hänger ihop med varandra mycket väl. Lättdrucken och kraftfullt rustik på samma gång. Riktigt bra.

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle marked 5SY. I presume it is the 2015 batch. This is nice dark, amber-maroon colored pour with a long lasting tan head and lacing. The aroma is sweet and malty mostly. A kind of grassy and pine hop note under it all as well as hay and maybe some wheat. Melted caramel too. Interesting aroma all around. Medium body. The taste leans sweet with a low to no hop bitterness at the end. A decent beer I have to say.

First beer of the new year! I am impressed by this delicious dunkelweizen-style winter warmer, which features both licorice-sweet wheat flavors as well as caramel and roasted chocolate malty flavors. Pours a murky brown-black, lots of white foam, with a sweet candy yeast aroma. Slight alcohol tartness in the finish, standard for a warmer. Interesting and enjoyable, paired well with the Parmesan cheese from my entree. Another well-done Anchor beer!

Bottle from Beers of Europe. . Dark brown pour with a beige head. Aromas of burnt toast, licorice toffee, cola and chocolate. Flavours of licorice toffee, black treacle and chocolate. Light bitter edge in the finish.

12 ounce bottle - $2.79 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours a very dark brown body with an inch of firm, lace-yielding, beige-colored foam.

Smell: Anise seed powder and rubber door stoppers ride atop the notes of dark malted wheat and tenuous touches of chocolate and fruit.

Taste: Roasty, wheaty with thin hints of everything from coffee to mild chocolate to store-brand cola to a vague nuttiness. Moderately sweet. Pinch of spicy nutmeg. Roasty, rubbery vibe mixed with anise arise midway, and, for me, the taste sort of derails at that point.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Lightly creamy on the tongue.

Overall: Though initially enticed by something a little bit different in a dark wheat, I really didnt care for this one.

Black pour. Outstanding head volume and retention. World class lacing.

Nice, but a bit light, nose of dark fruit (prune, raisin), wheat, caramel and a touch of earthy hops.

Medium body with a texture that approaches creamy. Superb carbonation level with a nice effervescent middle and a finely bubbled prickly finish.

The flavor profile is outstanding. It is moderately intense, highly complex and very well balanced. It begins with a wheat tartness that flows into the dark fruits - raisin and plum with prune underneath. A rich bready caramel balances the prune resulting in a slightly sweet background that highlights the plum. The middle hints at bitterness and tends to be roast rather than hop oriented. The finish is a slow fade of receding sweetness that succumbs to prune coupled with a subtle dryness.

Pours an opaque midnight brown with a full rich tan head. Aroma is prunes and spices. Taste is sweet roasted malt, dried fruit, molasses, dark chocolate, buttered biscuits and a bitterness brought on by the roasted malt. Also, the wheat malts render a smoother texture than the appearance would indicate. Wonderful.
Bottle from SB. Dark brown wit a medium tan head. Malty and fruity tones. Malt, fruit, spices and hops. Medium body with a nice malty / bitter fiinish.

December 28, 2015. Bottle. 
Almost black with a small creamy dark tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, cocoa, some fruit and spicy notes. Taste is light to medium sweet, light bitter. Finish is smooth roasted bitterness, some chocolate and light coffee, malty and light fruity sweetness along with some floral notes. Medium bodied, smooth with soft small bubble carbonation.
Good and very drinkable.
SB beställning, flaska. Banan sprit russin kolsyra. Vaniljglass på flaska. Inte illa alls. En fin vinterkompis.Bra med pepparkakor...

Dark weizenbock style beer, coffee and roasted malt aroma. The flavour Is fruity but heavily roasted malt, a dry bitter warming finish. This is a very original beers from the pioneers of the craft movement.
Brown with thin beige head; aroma israw malty alcohol; flava is sweet some chocolate some maple syrup notes blended with grain; feels medium slight fizz; finishes tangy sweet slight roasty notes

Bottle from systembolaget sweden. Big and lasting brown head. Very dark for a dunkel weissen. Light banana aroma with dark roasted malts and dark caramell. Roasted malt taste with a tuch of hard roasted bitterness. Fine body for a winter warmer.

@ Agards väg 26/12-15. Bottle from Systembolaget. Roasted malty with chocolate and light notes of dried fruits, also some wheat (in the aroma). Body is medium, the finish is roasted malty with chocolate.
Dark pour from the bottle. Taste is dark fruits, bread, caramel, malt and booze.

Yeast, butter toffee and caramel on the nose. The flavor is coffee, toffee and old water. No good bitterness which fills the upper part of the mouth a weak moment. Truly a lousy beer. Follow me @ Kung av öl @ Facebook for more pictures and ratings.

Bottle in Portland, OR. Nice deep, dark body with tan head. Nose is alcy, floral, plums, Taste is really nice of caramel, malts, plums and brown sugar. Really nice oily texture. With great kick in the finish. Just a really nice beer.

Bottle. Opaque pour with lsting beige head. Nose is roasted malt, wheat, a bit of dark cocoa and signature anchor house yeast and a bit of the (NB?) hops common to Anchor beers - but predominantly roasted malt. Great flavor - rich fine malts - textured Euro malt flavors are almost floral, and some more rough and spicy US malt notes make it exciting - great malt bill. Finish has a stout-like creaminess, but some bitter chocolate and wheeat smoothness - just a touch of bittering hops on the very end. Excellent - a roasty, creamy weizenbock. My kind of sipper.

A BIT BOOZY and fruity like brandy but with a short finish. deep dark color and smooth in the mouthfeel with an ashy dryness that complements the fruit like a bluberry, blackberry thing. interesting since i normally despise that blackberry thing. i guess its like wheat berry. not surprised its good beer from anchor but the deep black color seems different.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Pours black with a warm, reddish hue and a creamy, beige head. Lovely juicy, mushy aroma, lots of dried fruit and subtle roast. Rich, fat body, friendly estery, but dominated by the dried fruits and chocolate. Very delicious indeed. 221215
Confusing beer to me. Boozy, burnt and malty. Whet flavor? Lingering toasty notes with light chocolate notes.

Bottle from SB 151221.
Very dark brown body with dark beige creamy head. Heavy roasted aroma with coffee, dark chocolate, liquorice. Fruity palate with dried fruits, prunes. Espressofeeling. Nice and very well balanced bitterness in the end. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled. A black beer with a dark brown head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt and wheat. The flavor is sweet with notes of wheat, liquorice, spices, and roasted malt, leading to a bitter roasted finish.
33,5 cl. bottle. Dark brown colour with an off-white head. Aroma and flavour of roasted notes, wheat, yeast and caramel.

Aroma and taste is toasty malty, with some wheats notes, bready, caramel, so,e herbal hoppy notes into the finish.
35.5 cl bottle. Pours hazy brown with a deep amber glare, small tan head. Aroma is fruity, estery. Sweet, estery and slight fruity. Bitter, toasted and estery. Fruity and dark malty finish.

En överraskning från Anchor Brewing. Gissade att alkoholstyrkan skulle ligga på runt 5% men den är 7%. Mild och behagligt rostad malt. Torkad frukt, hasselnötter och torrt avslut. Vacker skumkrona. Aromen är anonym. Ett bra vinteröl.
(Bottle). Rich aroma and taste of malt, chocolate, spices, orange and hops. A very nice beer!

I took a first whiff right at the cracking open of the bottle and didnt like it much. It smelled like a stale fruit cake and overripe sapotes. Pour it into the appropriate glassware, though, and youll get banana bread, sultanas, more fruit cake, a hint of toffee, clove, some candied fruits, dark malts, and even some bubblegum. The mouthfeel is easy and silky, perhaps erring a bit on the undercarbonated side. The taste is fruity sweet, with an earthy, slightly spicy dryness that grows to overpower the fruity, estery flavors. There is less going on as the product flows under the palate than what you get through your nostrils, though. Had the gustatory experience lived up to the nose, this would have been much more memorable.

Flaska från SB. Smak och doft av humle, malt, choklad, svarta vinbär, plommon, trä, korn, bröd, fikon, vete med toner av örter och lakrits. Fruktig, fyllig, frisk, torr, lagom sötma, go munkänsla, rund och len, fin beska, bra balans mellan smakerna. Mycket gott vinteröl!
Bottle - small tan foamy head, pitch black color, big mildly roasty malty aroma and flavor, caramel like full body finish, pretty good overall

Bottle from Systembolaget.

Dark brown with a small tan head. Roasted malt, wheat, some licorice, grass and some hints of hops. Medium body and with a fairly dry finish.

Bottle from Appellation Wines.
Appearance -close to opaque black with a decent fawn head.
Nose - toffee, creamy a touch of banana.
Taste - more of the same. 
Palate - close to medium bodied with a creamy texture and a fairly good finish.
Overall - I expected this to be pale so a surprise from start to finish.

Anchor never strays too far from its German roots and that seems especially apparent with Winter Wheat. Im not sure Ive seen an American brewery take on a winter-time Dunkelweizen, but it seems like a damn good idea to me. Winter Wheat pours mostly black with a dark-colored head. Aroma has coffee, buttery chocolate, and bread. Flavor balances malty sweetness and earthy bitterness. Taste is nutty, bittersweet, and fairly complex. You get roasted malts, spicy cocoa, and rich grains. All around, this is a classy brew. Its a malty treat for the cold.

Bottle - Anchor is often stupidly overlooked by the modern beer need, but they still consistently make great product - the flying cloud stout was excellent, and this beer is nearly as good - stout-like appearance (black with a tan head) - nose of dark breads, raisin, chocolate, light tartness, hazelnut - lovely, round mouthfeel, with full, soft carbonation - flavor is a complex blend of dark breads, medium sweet chocolate, modederate, balancing acidity, dried cherries, raisin, with a moderate finishing spiciness.

Bottle from Briarwood Liquor: Poured a dark brown liquid that was opaque while a thick pillow of foam cap rested on top. Aroma is tantalizing with a whiff of barrel aging wood, lightly roast malt and sourness from the yeast. The taste is tart with notes of sour and bitterness while also having a dried fruit flavor of plum, grape raisin, and apricot profile. The tartness makes this beer remind me of an English barleywine but the yeast used assures me that it is a dunkelweizen. Packs a punch with an ABV of 7 but at the same time the tart flavor makes this beer difficult to drink more than a couple bottles of it. Only picked this up because I had never seen it and didnt want to miss out on it but distributing a winter wheat beer during the months of summer is unheard of, and Im not sure if I agree with it.

Sampled December 2014
A steady pour into my globe glass produces a fat-two-finger thick, nicely brown stained, dark tan colored head. The beer is a rich, dark, dark, chocolate brown color that is almost black; it is dark enough that it is quite opaque, even when held up directly to the light. The aroma smells of dark fruit and rich maillard-leaning malt; prunes, raisins, and rich caramelized grain, as well as a wholesome, molasses sweetened, dense, dark, sweet, bread note (think of a sweet, holiday bread of some sort, or perhaps a dense fruit cake without the fake fruit notes).

The beer is nicely carbonated which accentuates a lightly bitter, smooth roast character in the finish. The body has a certain richness and chewiness to it without hindering this from being quite quaffable. Flavors of roasted raisins, slightly burnt prunes (is there a hint of carameilzed banana and clove here too?), as well as a lightly sweet, toasted, dark grain character, a bit of coffee like roast character, and a rich, dark maltiness that is reminiscent of a rich, deep dark bock (though not nearly as heavy or concentrated).

This is a really nice beer, somehow it is greater than the sum of its parts, as I cant quite put my finger on why I am enjoying this beer as much as I am. In the end it is tasty and interesting, and sometimes you really dont need more than that in a beer.

When you think wheat beer you tend to think of lightly-colored brews with fluffy heads and banana notes. Anchor Winter Wheat is about 180 degrees removed from that image as its dark as a porter and opts more for roasted maltiness and hints of dark fruit. In fact, this probably is better judged as a porter than any kind of wheat beer, though I suppose specialty grain would be the appropriate style to view it as. Its certainly an interesting beer and definitely has a unique recipe, and in that aspect it works pretty well.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a weizen glass. It was bottled on 9/26/14 and cost $2.75 ($0.23 per ounce).

Appearance: Deep black in color with red highlights. Pours to a large, brown, foamy head which mostly dissipates, but laces fairly well.

Smell: Mild nose with hints of dark malt, some fruity sweetness, and milky/dairy notes.

Taste: The first thing I notice about this beer is that it really doesnt taste particularly wheaty, despite the brewerys description of so many different varieties of wheat used in the brewing process. Its closer to a standard porter as the dark malt is the most prominent flavor and it finishes  initially  with a dry bitterness and a dark chocolate sensation. Eventually, that confectionery note gives way to a general mélange of dark fruit and dark malt. The wheat is surprisingly muted, creating for just a slight tanginess on the finish. I did enjoy the almost lactose-like character, but I wanted so much more. Why not ferment with Bavarian yeast to give it a chocolate-covered banana taste? No that wouldve been memorable.

Drinkability: I was rather shocked to see the 7% ABV on the label, since Anchor Winter Wheat drinks more like a light-bodied summer wheat. The mouthfeel is soft and calm and goes down smooth like a hefeweizen. However, it doesnt have the gusto or raw energy of a strong beer, which it should. I appreciate the easy drinkability, but Ill penalize it for finishing entirely too clean.

Bottle. Dark brown with a tall but short-lasting brown head. Malty and yeasty aroma is roast and ink and soy sauce black malt, nutty and toasty wheat, pepper and sea salt, light touches of plastic / vinyl. Esters provide some amount of fruit character, hops are lightly herbal and grassy, and with warmth the malt opens up into more of a raisin / date character. Medium body, chewy and syrupy in the mouth, simple dark caramel malt turning to burnt popcorn in a short, sweet, watery finish. The aroma seemed decent to begin before the head collapsed and the salt + pepper liveliness was replaced by a simple burnt cola and raisin aroma with the ink and plastic off-notes creeping. For me the flavor balance is wonky, the body too syrupy and the finishing flavor of burnt pancake batter unpleasant.

Bottle. Orange, banana, light clove, and chocolate malt aroma. Dark chestnut with giant tan head. Sweet lightly fruity chocolate malt and lightly bitter herbal flavor. Nice body. A good beer - tastes more like a schwarzbier though with minimal weizen characteristics.

12 oz bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a big clumpy tan head that has very good retention. The aroma is mild and understated with grains, fruits and chocolates. The taste is very earthy with more spicy grains, chocolate and plums. The palate is full and creamy with soft carbonation. Finishes long dry and spicy. Overall: Decent brewski.

Rich, super deep dark brown coloured body with only a tiny bit of light getting through the bottom, making it around 90% opaque, all with a rich, four centimetre tall luscioius brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, alcohol, coffee and a hint of spices - very nice and pungent, all with a slightly subdued scent. Medium-bodied; Rich chocolatey and roasted malt flavours with hints of coffee, raisins, figs, prunes and way more chocolate - super rich and pungent with not much wheat notes at all. Aftertaste shows quite a bit of the sugars with a milky, spicey and yeastie kick at the end - very nice, super pungent and a great finish for the style and for any beer. Overall, a super impressive beer that I wasnt expecting from the outset with a lot of flavour, rich body and somehow more sweetness and body than I could have imagine - all tucked in that stubby twelve ounce bottle. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Whole Foods in Washington (Foggy Bottom), DC on 11-November-2014 for US$2,49 sampled at home in Washington on 27-December-2014.

Bottle. Moderate aromas all around, with toasted, cereal and cookie for the malt, herbs and dough for the hops and yeast, with toffee and a hint of rust in the background. Head is small, fizzy, tan with fair lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is clear very dark brown. Flavor starts lightly to moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly bittersweet. Palate is on the fuller side of medium, creamy, with a fizzy carbonation. The aromas of this Dunkelweizen is fairly good, but the flavor is truly excellent.

Aroma of mild chocolate and sweet bread. Ebony in color with a huge dark tan head. Rich sweet wheat flavors. Complex with notes of dark raisin, bitter chocolate, and other dark fruit. Dry bitternss balances nicely with the sweetness. Finishes dry with a slightly lingering bitterness that is even. Slightly watery mouth feel. Nice beer.

Bottle from Liquor Collection 261114. This beer was so not what I expected, it was much better. Dense and dark with a tan head. Great winter beer although it doesnt really feel like winter as I sit here in Waikiki drinking this beer.
From bottle. Deep dark color. Aroma is roasted malt, prune, and caramel. Taste is sweetly smokey, with prune, dark wheat, and toffee notes. Substantial body and nice lingering finish.

I wasnt going to pick this up, but a fellow beer shopper at the grocery store assured me that it was a Dunkelweizen, so here we are. Nice pour into a Hefeweizen glass (natch), dark enough brown body to almost appear black, topped by a lofty light brown head. Its got a fairly sweet aroma, chocolate syrup, whole grain bread, some fruitiness. The taste, too, is sweet, but not cloyingly so. Its a blending of bittersweet and milk chocolate, old fruit, and a touch of ash. Not a bad beer.

I poured this into a weizen glass.
The appearance was a nice looking dark brown color with a two finger off white foamy head that quickly dissipated. Foamy speckled lacing graces the glass nicely.
The smell, unlike a fair amount of dunkelweizens Ive had has a lot of roasted bready notes up front. As it warms, theres a nice sweet banana connotation to it.
The taste took the roast with the bread and added a light chocolate to seem to have made it taste like banana/chocolate toast. Cool, I think I like it.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a decent degree of sessionability about it. Theres a nice rolling roasted banana chocolate goodness over my tongue.
Overall, for me, I like it, its a bit different than true dunkelweizens but still fits the bill for the most part. A nice winters brew!

Pour is a black with a large creamy tan head. Aroma Is like a porter. Lots of chocolate and roasted barley malt. Flavor is roasty and chocolate but then comes a nice wheat. Like eating a handful of slightly kilned cracked wheat. Mouth feel is heavy but also silky smooth. KInda hodgepodge of styles here. Roasty like a porter but plenty of wheat aspects make this pretty solid.

Pours dark with a very thick, creamy tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, light chocolate. Very smooth and creamy, chocolate, roasted malt, a little smoky and nice offsetting bitterness to keep it from being too sweet. Delicious.

Nice winter beer. Love dunkleweozen and this is right around that area. Great option for winter that isn't porter or stout

Bottle. Pours clear reddish black, medium brown head, creamy with nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is roasty, wheat, pumpernickel breads. Flavor is medium sweet and very light bitter, roasted wheats, faint smoky notes. Medium body, slight astringency. Solid beer!

12 ounce bottle purchased at The Davis Beer Shoppe. The aroma has some sweet chocolate hints as well as some light roast. Minimally phenolic. Slight metallic house character is also there. Opaque black body with a medium to large, creamy tan head. Great lacing, and great retention. This beer starts with a good deal of roasted maltiness as well as some moderately sweet chocolate flavors in the middle. Becomes a little dusty and husky later on with the wheat flavors. Finishes lightly metallic, and pretty badass. MUCH better than their spiced Christmas Ale. One of my favorite Anchor Beers. Home Run.

Surprised to see this wheat beer look like a porter and taste like a dunkel bock. Guess I should have read the label! Despite the surprise, its quite pleasant. Smells and tastes of toffee and roast caramel, moderately sweet but finishes dry enough to be refreshing. Maybe a hint of spice; not sure. Has the superior mouthfeel in carbonation and chewiness per the usual Anchor style. A nice, easygoing winter warmer-type beer. Still never had a bad one from Anchor.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2014 I hadnt heard anything about this beer before I picked up a sixer at Safeway. I was thinking wheat beer, so naturally I was surprised when the beer poured jet black with a tan head. The aroma is interesting, but mild with hints of root beer, licorice, light banana and cocoa. The flavor has more roasted notes with dark fruit, licorice, wheat, cream soda and subtle raw banana. The mouthfeel is pretty light and moderately frothy. Overall, an interesting beer that grew on me as I drank it. Actually, I picked up another sixer since I enjoyed it so much. Very good stuff.
You know what? This is pretty damn good. Reminds of some of the darker German wheat beers--little sweeter than I would have expected. Looks beautiful. Good job on this one. 12oz pour from bottle.

12 oz. bottle.

Poured clear but very dark brown with a large, creamy tan head that had very good retention and left excellent patterned lacing on the glass. No sediment.

Aroma: "enticing", as claimed, with faint hops and spiciness over a solid malt base. Hints of dark fruits, toffee and roasted nuts.

Excellent balanced flavor with subtle complexity. Dark bread with hints of licorice, roasted nuts, coffee (in the aftertaste), and molasses. Mildly bitter. 

Feel: Excellent! Medium body with a near creamy texture and ample soft carbonation.
Didn't see this coming. Pours deep, dark brown with a fluffy tan head. Not your everyday Wheat beer. Aroma of cocoa powder. Taste is malt forward with spices that linger. Bottle from Trader Joe's.

Very dark brown but not black crystal clear body with a small finely textured brown head. Aromas of cocoa and roasted malt and maybe a slight sour tinge. Cocoa and dark chocolate come out in the taste which is a combination of a dunkleweizen and a bock beer. Full body probably from the wheat which gives it a creamy texture. Definitely malt forward but there is a slight astringency and bitterness which balances out some of the chocolate sweetness.

Dark brown pour with a thick foamy tan head.
Aroma is chocolate malt very light banana. Se coffee. Bit bland.
Flavour is coffee roasted, light banana again, tailing off to a faint coffee finish.
A bit homogenized for me. Light flab, light aroma. Was expecting/hoping for a bit more from this one.

Bottled. Dark reddish black pour. Yeast. Wheat. Malt. Spice. Honestly pretty darned good. More like a Weiss bock.

12oz bottle. Clear red-black body with small beige head. Aroma is moderately sweet, spicy, some cherry, licorice, light caramel. Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, some cherry, light spicy. Light-medium body.

Anchor Winter Wheat has a very thick, beige, crackling head, an extremely dark brown appearance, with lighter brown around the edges, and decently heavy lacing left on the glass. The aroma is rich, sweet, bready, metallic, nutty, and crusty. Taste is of those elements, with not so harsh bitterness. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy and somewhat velvety, and Anchor Winter Wheat finishes semi-dry and pretty well drinkable. RJT
On tap at Capitol Beer & Tap Room. Pours near black with a nice tan head and a light brown malt aroma. There is a dry wheat flavor with a slightly sweet finish.

12oz bottle. 12 oz single from Biggie Wine & Spirits. Almost black appearance with a light tan head. Aroma of mild spices, bready malts, light roast, earthy hops, toasted grains and bitter chocolate. Similar flavor, a little heavy on the spices but otherwise a pretty tasty dark beer, almost like a porter.

12oz bottle picked up at Trader Joes. It pours with a mahogany colored body that supports a thin dark tan head. The aroma offers up molasses, a bit of cherry, some smooth winter spicy notes and a smattering of roasted malts. The taste starts winter spicy and then heading into molasses and spicy black licorice. To midway it picks up a light dark roasted malt note, a bit of woodiness as well as thin snippets of cherry meat. This is a nice winter ale with a pleasing balance of spices and malts.

Draft. This might need to be listed as a dunkelweizen, it isnt one but I was shocked when it poured a dark brown with a creamy tan head. The aroma is mixed cereals, bakers chocolate, spices. Flavor is interesting, typical anchor yeast with a balsamic note. There is a lot of black currant, acidic coffee, some peat, cocoa, spice, savory. This is an interesting beer, no doubt a dry and savory one, good for the holidays I guess.

12 oz single from Trader Joe in Salem OR.
$1.34
Wow this is not what i expected!.. Dark brown body with a lovely creamy and bubbly tan head.
Aroma of semi dark chocolate, milky coffee slight floral hop..nice.
Taste is incredibly creamy smooth and chocolate winning the day 
Very nice mouth feel..excellent in fact.

Pours deep brown with a small of white head. Aroma is earthy, roast, caramel, plum and wheat. Taste is sweet with mild tartness. Medium bodied with a slick smooth texture. Overall this is a great winter warmer, it melds together perfectly.

Bottle from the Davis Co-Op. Pours quite dark brown with a dark tan head. Aroma is not hoppy, more a mix of dark malt and med dark fruit. With some chocolate. Med body. Flavor is dark malt, med dark fruit, chocolate and tends to end with a earthy flavor reminiscent of aged cheese. (Think CowGirl RedHawk approaching ripe). Finishing not very sweet, but not very bitter either. Quite tasty and interesting.

Cola body, with decent head and carbonation. Lovely blend of smooth roasted malts, wheat, and yeast to conjure a dark fall night after a good seasons harvest. Likewise the body is quite well-crafted. Perfect body pitch, with flavors of smooth roast barley punctuated by a spritz of crackling black patent, accompanied by a bountiful heaping of wheat and screwed together by well-suited yeast that contributes an edging of esters and phenols. Definitely a good one from Anchor. I know I said the same thing about their IPA the day it was available in SF. Like their newish IPA, it has a traditional take. Although, I find this to be more like a wheat bock.

12 oz. bottle. Dark brownish/ near black pour with a tan head. Lots of lacing. Aroma of chocolate, toffee, caramel. Plenty of that classic anchor yeast. Flavor of dark breads, mild bitterness, fruity yeast. Fairly interesting. Medium body and lively carbonation. Finishes earthy with mild bitterness.
Aroma is bubblegum, fruit/berries/bread and mild dark fruit. The flavor is dark fruit, malts, a hint of tobacco, fruit and a mildly sour/alcoholic finish.
I thought this was very good. Its nice to see a winter warmer using wheat. Dark brown, with rich malty character. A little slick on the tongue and well balanced sweetness.

This was a pleasant surprise. Pours quite dark with a large tan pillowy head. The aroma has cream, vanilla, smooth wheat, chocolate and dark fruits. It has a full body that is very smooth and lush with gentle carbonation. The flavor begins with roastiness, chocolate, husks, berries, cream, vanilla, light char and wood. The finish is quite dry with more wood character, dark chocolate and smooth vanilla. Really nice and hearty. Would be great for cold winter nights.

Sweet roasted malt flavor has a subtle wheat-like nuance with more dried fruit, like dark cherries and raisins. Well done!

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a deep brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has lots of sweet dark wheat with some dark fruits and a bit of toffee underlying. Flavor has a good amount of earthy dark grains that is joined by sweet wheat.
Soft cocoa, dry roast, hazelnut, mild cherry acidity, light clove-y spice. Really solid and unique winter offering.
Pours deep mahogany into a shaker. Tan head with good retention recedes to hug rim. Dark chocolate and manure aromas. Dry and soft with sweet chocolate and earthy manure front to back.

Pours two finger of tan head on a dark brown body.
The aroma is mild caramel with some dry grain.
The taste has lots of roasted malt and caramel. Nice profile.
The texture is smooth with a thicker body.
Besides the almost non-existent aroma, this is a nice drink.

Bottle from Table and Vine. Dark brown with lasting dense tan head and full lace. Spicy clovey cakey bready aroma with a touch of alcohol. Roasted caramel and tangy plummy fruity sweetness with medium herbal bitterness and dry finish with some lingering herbal bitterness and licorice. Medium light body. A very pleasant surprise. Wasnt sure anything could wake Anchor up. Excellent. Should be a weizen bock.

Not usually too excited about wheat beers but this your everyday wheat. Lots of porter character in the nose, look and flavor, with an added complexity and soft creamy palate especially from the winter wheat. Roasty and fruity. Glad it aint replacing OSA, but a welcome addition.
Bottle from trader joes...second person to rate!...pour is black with light creamy head...no lacing....taste is malt,licorice,metallic....different....some spice.....good.

Hmm. First rate of this? Maybe. Bottle from Trader Joes. Pours a dark brown color with a medium tan head. The aroma is big spicy and malty notes. The flavor is licorice, fruit, metal, roast perhaps, ash. Very sweet and mellow, spicy. Quite nice. A solid winter warmer. Would work well with Turkey.
